This post by @b0rk debunks some myths about blogging (which I don't do much of), but I think a lot of it applies equally well to developing a talk.

It's very freeing to let go of myths such as:

myth: you need to be original
myth: you need to be an expert
myth: posts need to be 100% correct
myth: you need to explain every concept
myth: more material is always better

https://jvns.ca/blog/2023/06/05/some-blogging-myths/

last_post.content:
This vertically oriented logarithmic map spans nearly 20 orders of magnitude, taking us from planet Earth to the edge of the observable #Universe.

As insurers refuse to write new homeowners insurance policies in California, a real estate crash is on the way.

If you can't get insurance, you can't get a mortgage. It's that simple.

Climate change will bankrupt people, businesses, communities, states, and nations.

https://www.sfchronicle.com/california/article/insurance-allstate-fires-18130622.php

title: Pluralistic: The long lineage of private equity’s looting (02 June 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
Why didn’t Sears, with its massive catalog and network, grow into an online giant instead of Amazon? From landlords to healthcare, why is everything getting worse - and more expensive - at the same time? And what does this have to do with a German corporation whose slave labor camp was worse than #Auschwitz?

@pluralistic answers those questions and more in this tour-de-force linkblog. via @LLS (🙏🏻)

https://pluralistic.net/2023/06/02/plunderers/

#Capitalism #Neoliberalism

This week marks 10 years since Edward #Snowden's global surveillance revelations started, including that the NSA's #XKeyscore program was specifically targeting #Wikipedia users.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/31/nsa-top-secret-program-online-data

For the next week, I'm taking a break from this account -- but not the Fediverse. This is to lower my impact of redis on calckey.social.

Consequently, all my messages will be sent from @atomicpoet@atomicpoet.org, which is my single-user server operated by myself and managed by #SpaceHost.

For anything mission critical, this account may occasionally boost messages from @atomicpoet@atomicpoet.org.

If you're thinking of following @atomicpoet@atomicpoet.org, remember that it's primarily used for talking about non-Fediverse related stuff.

For this week, I'm making an exception and will be sharing Fediverse-related stuff on atomicpoet.org. Nevertheless, please don't get angry if you see stuff pertaining to anime, work-outs, video games, music, and other recreational topics. No matter what, atomicpoet.org is still my personal Fediverse server 😉

In advance, I apologize for any inconvenience this has caused.

title: Release Notes for Safari Technology Preview 171

last_post.content:
Safari Technology Preview 171 adds:
- `@font-face { src: tech() }` and `@supports font-tech()`
- `@font-face` `size-adjust`
- additional language support for list counters: 29 Ethiopic, 3 Korean, and 4 Chinese styles
- renaming `leading-trim` to `text-box-trim`and `text-edge` to `text-box-edge`
- the new `<search>` element in HTML
- `AbortSignal.any()`
- `ServiceWorkerRegistration.getNotifications()`
- `getDisplayMedia` video track clone resizing

Plus a lot more… https://webkit.org/blog/14200/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-171/

The Rust I Wanted Had No Future

Great blog post by @graydon about what would have happened in the alternate universe, where Graydon is BDFL of Rust.

"If I'd stayed in charge (...) the result would have been, I think, fairly unpopular. The Rust I Wanted probably had no future, or at least not one anywhere near as good as The Rust We Got. The fact that there was *any* path that achieved the level of success the language has seen so far is frankly miraculous."

title: EU-U.S. Terminology and Taxonomy for Artificial Intelligence

last_post.content:
Recent dict of AI terms put out by EU is useful, but:
LAWMAKERS!
Talking to US, UK, AND EU!
**Accuracy is ONE SPECIFIC METRIC in AI**
And usually not the right one.
With classification, usu you want "precision", "recall"--NOT ACCURACY.
Thread 🧵 explaining!

title: Hay – yes, hay – is sucking the Colorado River dry

last_post.content:
#Agriculture uses 80% of #ColoradoRiver water annually, and alfalfa hay is responsible for over a third of that.

In 2020, 40% of #California's alfalfa was shrink-wrapped, containerized, and shipped overseas.

"A century-old legal doctrine compels farmers to use as much river water as they’re allotted, or else lose access to the unused portion in the future. That perverse incentive... means that wasteful irrigation methods have not gone out of fashion."

https://www.hcn.org/articles/south-colorado-river-hay-yes-hay-is-sucking-the-colorado-river-dry

Ok, I used the Apple Vision Pro for about 30 minutes. It’s good. It’s expensive. It’s VERY design, and MUCH engineering. I’m intrigued as hell. https://techcrunch.com/2023/06/05/first-impressions-yes-apple-vision-pro-works-and-yes-its-good/

One reason I think Apple’s Vision Pro could succeed over the long term: people actually really want heads-up displays like the ones they’ve seen in sci-fi. https://www.platformer.news/p/apple-has-a-vision

title: During Pride month, journalists should be ashamed - Press Watch

last_post.content:
This is a very good summary of a depressing situation. Journalists should indeed be ashamed of themselves. The endless procession of timid "okay but the Nazis trying to exterminate queer people are just another political viewpoint" articles, particularly in the American press, is truly an indictment on the sheer spinelessness of the profession
